reviewText:
Apparently I have to give it a thumbs-up or thumbs-down.  There's no option here to abstain.  I mean, yeah, it's okay with another human player, but it WOULD be LOADS of fun if I could use controllers, configure or even view my controls, or play with more than just two people.

Those three issues are basically what's keeping me from recommending this game.  I wouldn't pay $20 for it, but it's probably worth it if it goes on sale.

NOTE TO STEAM:  This is NOT a negative review.  It's a NEUTRAL review.  Your options are too limited.

reviewText:
+ Hilarious questions and dialogue
+/- Generous amount of episodes, but no DLC for PC
- Only 2 players?

Twisted trivia to make you and your party guests laugh out loud. Yes, you can play by yourself, but this is absolutely a party game, like the You Don't Know Jack of the 90's. So why, oh why, can you only play 2 players? Supposedly, it's because only 2 people can feasably use the keyboard at the same time. I guess Jellyvision didn't know you can use game pads on your PC. Sheesh.

All gripes aside, the game is hilarious. Sometimes, answering the question right is a matter of deciphering the strange wording of the questions, which can be funny or frustrating, depending on how clever you are. Be ready for anything, this is not a standardized test.

It sure seems as if this will be the last 'traditional game' iteration of You Don't Know Jack. Now with mobile games, you can play against a bunch of people you don't know on Facebook, instead of in the same room with your good friends shouting and acting silly. Huge improvement, social media sure is making our lives better! /sarcasm

Well, that's the way the Cookie crumbles!

7.0/10
Trivia for those who don't care if they lose, when a good fart joke is so much more enjoyable.

reviewText:
I was a big fan of YDKJ back in the day, and was excited when I saw this remake was available. Unfortunately, it disappoints on a few key fronts and I can't wholeheartedly recommend it:

1) 2-player only. Many older YDKJ version offer more players, and console versions of this remake offer 4-player. This is a game where more players = more fun, so the lack of 4-play is disappointing.
2) No net play. While Jack is best face to face, and none of the older Jacks had this either, if I recall... it should be a standard feature on a modern remake like this.
3) No controller support. This is probably the reason for the 2-player limitation. Both players have to huddle around the keyboard, which is a bit lame. I'd like to hook a laptop up to the TV and give each player an xbox360 controller to buzz in with... but no dice. This is another feature available on consoles, by the way.

In summary, this is tha YDKJ you know and love from 1996... which is 2014 is a bit disappointing. The PC version is also surpassed in features by the console version.

reviewText:
FANTASTIC!

While it may seem to lack a few things from the retro style of YDKJ some of us are used to, this seems to be able to handle it's own, although it does have a bit TOO much of that Syndicated feel to it (much like how corporate takes over a very humorous title and tries to outsell and overhype it). Don't get me wrong, it's fun, I'd reccomend buying it and playing it if you like trivia games with a twist, but just..something about it feels lacking. Maybe it's just the nostalgia.

Either way, this is a fun game for you and a friend to play. The commentary has that same near dry flavor that YDKJ does so well, and the inclusion of the Wrong Answer of the Game almost adds a complete new spin on how you play the game. It's actually just as rewarding and funny to lose trying to find it, as it is to win the game.

PROS:
-Great writing, excellent mind twister type puzzles, LOOOOTS of content for questions, classic YDKJ segments (DisOrDat, Jack Attack)

CONS:
-Slightly repetative in terms of question format, almost copy of the previous games

reviewText:
This is a really fun trivia game. The formula is very simple: it's a trivia game show on your computer. The humor is great, and everything about this game is very witty, from the questions to the host to the commercials. I loved the old YDKJ games, and this is more of the same. I've had a lot of fun with this already, and I plan to scour the game's 73 episodes.

This game does have multiplayer, but only for two players, and no online play. I still plan to play quite a bit of multiplayer, though.

I picked this game up for full price the moment I saw it on Steam, and it was definitely worth it.

reviewText: Includes a lot of the same charm and challenging questions that I enjoyed when the original series was popular in the 90s, though revamped from using randomized questions to a selection of episodes, or the same questions and special challenges in the same order. There are a many episodes available and this does allow you to challenge low scores at a later date. The game foolishly lacks a multiplayer component, which makes no sense, and I'll admit has caused me to not play very many of the episodes myself. However, there are precious few good trivia games out there any more and this definitely remains true to what made YDKJ great in the past, yet with nicely updated HD graphics. A good game to have handy if you like trivia. Three stars out of four.

reviewText:
Love trivia games? This game's for you!

Hate trivia games? This game's also for you!

Let me explain that second assertion. When Jellyvision (now Jackbox Games) developed the first You Don't Know Jack, they weren't that fond of trivia games, either. So they made a trivia game that united trivia lovers and trivia haters in riotous bouts of laughter. And the rest is history.

Okay, maybe more of a poorly sourced Wikipedia article, but a SEXY BEAST of a poorly sourced Wikipedia article.

reviewText:
My, oh my.  Cookie Masterson and the JellyVision team return.

Is it a reboot?  Sorta yeah.  Is it a remake?  Nah, not really.  Is it the same as it ever was?  Yes and no.

The questions are all new, as is the dialogue and there is a slight change in the key assignments, but Cookie, the interface, Jack Attacks, DisOrDats and screwing should be familiar to any YDKJ veteran.  What is VASTLY improved are the production values.  Not only had YDKJ gone all high-def (‘n stuff), but there's full-screen support for this bad boy (woohoo!).  The addition of the Wrong Answer of the Game" prizes
date: Nocturnal Admissions and Who’s the Dummy shake it up a little bit
recommended: in a good way.  I am
voteText: on the fence about the achievements (Getting "mouth breather" is not exactly something I'm proud of).\n\nWhile I don't exactly miss the "Gibberish Question" portions
votesHelpful: it was actually a thing on the older games).  Rumor has it
votesTotal: some other versions of this have 3-player support (Don't hold me to that
votesFunny: as I am speaking for the PC/Steam version.  Mostly
column16: I REALLY miss the 7 or 15 question selection some of the older YDKJ games had.\n\nDo any of my negatives turn me off to it?  No
column17: absolutely not.  The new YDKJ is like having your best friend over to your house after losing touch for 10 years.  He/she has certainly changed
column18: but they're (likely) still the same person and you can still relate.  In the case of YDKJ
column23: they look better than I do for having 10+ years go by since I last saw 'em!\n"

reviewText:
Phenomenal game!

I have played every YDKJ game and every YDKJ game has been a blast!  Though missing cool things like Gibberish Questions and the rare Impossible Question, this version of has things like Who's the Dummy and Cookie's Forturne Cookie.  The addition of the Wrong Answer aspect will keep you on your toes.  They still retain Dis or Dat and the every joyful Jack Attack.

The PC version, oddly enough, is inferior in its multiplayer control schemes.  Whereas the Xbox 360 version allows four, each on their own controller, the PC version only has a two player option and the control scheme is a bit...rough.

Still, if you are a champion of the Social Outcast achievement, such as myself, the single player still has that YDKJ feel with an updated temperament.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A great game for anyones collection.

For those of you not familiar with the series- YDKJ is a hilarious trivia game that was a staple back in the 90's.  This modern rendition shouldn't disappoint.

It's definately best played vs someone sitting right next to you, although single player is still plenty of fun.

The humors pretty good, and there's sure to be laughs in there for just about anyone.


Really the only complaint I have is that the Steam version just seems to tagging along in terms of support as they were obviously targeting other markets with this release.  i.e. - No Steamcloud support, no online multiplayer, no control customization.

I recall the old YDKJ's supporting 1-4 players, but this one only supports 2 players.

Apart from that, I still highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Purchased at $3

I truly don't know jack. I guess spending my whole life playing video games has taught me absolutely nothing about the world around me. Chalk it up to ignoring all news and pop culture. Anyone I have over and play this with is sure to stomp my ♥♥♥. I still enjoy it though. I see why this series has been around so long. It's about as good as trivia can get in video game form. Very entertaining. PC needs more party games like this. Get drunk with a friend and have fun.

Be warned though. There is no online multiplayer. There is no 3 or 4 player. There is no controller support either. You will need to use joy2key or something else to use controllers. Also, it doesn't seem to respond to inputs in Big Picture Mode. If you can, go for the console version. Else, get this on the cheap like I did.

Also, play the facebook game. It's basically the exact same presentation. It's the only thing I made a facebook account for.

reviewText: Do you like multiple choice questions? Do you like questions so absurd you barely have enough time to wrap your head around them? Do you like listening to a cynical show host degrade you for everything you do, right or wrong? Then this is the game for you! With the zaniest trivia this side of Cuba (Cuba? I'm sticking with Cuba.), you're gonna have a great flippin' time. Excellent 2-player game as well: Watch your friends squirm as you screw them (you heard me) and get the wrong answer of the game, rocketing yourself into an unreachable first place. All around, 10/10 game. I seriously can't find anything wrong with the game outside of local multiplayer only, which I feel works with this kind of game. Pick this up ASAP.

reviewText:
Purchased at $3

I truly don't know jack. I guess spending my whole life playing video games has taught me absolutely nothing about the world around me. Chalk it up to ignoring all news and pop culture. Anyone I have over and play this with is sure to stomp my ♥♥♥. I still enjoy it though. I see why this series has been around so long. It's about as good as trivia can get in video game form. Very entertaining. PC needs more party games like this. Get drunk with a friend and have fun.

Be warned though. There is no online multiplayer. There is no 3 or 4 player. There is no controller support either. You will need to use joy2key or something else to use controllers. Also, it doesn't seem to respond to inputs in Big Picture Mode. If you can, go for the console version. Else, get this on the cheap like I did.

Also, play the facebook game. It's basically the exact same presentation. It's the only thing I made a facebook account for.

reviewText: Great game with lots of fun to be had. The only problem is that the concept is too much for some people. For example, I was playing with my cousin and he got all pissy when the question was confusing to figure out. So, i say to him that's the point of the game to figure out the question, then answer. After this, I tell him what the question is asking and he still doesn't get it right and just quits. So, make sure friends are not idiots.

reviewText: If you're trying to get this game to work on something with a high DPI (what Apple would call retina) display, it may crash. If it does, make a short-cut to it on your desktop, go into the properties of the short-cut, select the Compatibility" tab
date: check the box labeled "Disable display scaling on high DPI settings"
recommended: and then click OK. If this was your problem
hoursPlayed: the game will run fine when you use the short-cut and scale itself automatically (I think THQ implemented it with vectorized graphics and text anyway). It would be nice if Steam could do this for folks with older games in which it's necessary
voteText: although this may be one of the few."
